dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're at the checkout counter with two pregnancy tests. It's evident they’ve pulled their clothes on hastily. Bur still holding his face where Verona slapped him.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Sorry. I don’t know why I did that.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Have I ever done that before?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It just seemed the right thing at the time.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’s okay. After the initial shock, it was kind of exciting. BURT FARLANDER is white, about 30, looking like he could either an assistant professor or a lunatic shooting peopl from a tower -- there’s that funny-crazy look in his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s very smart, very straightforward and earnest, but a eccentric -- the type of guy who’s never done drugs, but often gone camping nude. He reads widely but not deeply enough, and has many strange hobbies, which he indulges f short periods of time but with utter seriousness. The las such hobby was bear-tracking. He works in the insurance industry. VERONA DE TESSANT is of mixed race - her mom was white, h father black. She’s very cute, diminutive, a bit feisty. She’s a medical illustrator and has the necessary combina of the artistic and the exacting. Of the pair, she is the more socially presentable and stable, and finds herself apologizing for her partner at least once a week. Still, is devoted to him and he to her. Her beauty and sense of humor are alluring and inspire many admirers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona’s driving.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I can’t wait.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I’m pulling over.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We’re ten minutes away. No. She pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What're you... Verona is already out of the car and pushing down her jea

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: At least get off the shoulder! Sounds of urine hitting gravel.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’ll be less accurate out here.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to do this ina bathroom. The air out here is different. The alkaline...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: The alkaline? The alkaline? Just... please. I’m done. Hold this on the end here. Verona hands him the stick. He holds it at a distance, th way you would a steaming pot, while she pulls up her pant

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Lay it flat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Lay it flat? Like on the road? Should I lay it on the road?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No...on the dashboard or something. Verona gets back in the driver’s seat. They’re staring at the stick, which has been placed on

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s time. Turn on the light. in the car, the dash. Burt turns on the light. It’s far too dim to see anything

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: That’s the light? That’s your interior light?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What? Yes that’s my interior light? What’s wrong with my interior light? You've never had a problem with my interior light before...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Just-- Shut up. Turn on the headlights. She gets out and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both bathed in the white light of the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. I can’t tell. I need a control sample. Here. She hands him a second stick from the package.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No. This is insane. Let’s do it in the bathroom. Verona gives him a look. Burt turns away from the car. So of urine hitting gravel.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Okay, now bring it over here.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But you said not on the road.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t care what I said. We need the light. Verona lays Burt’s stick next to the other one on the roa Her movements are meticulous, precise. Burt reads the instructions while they’re waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So basically one line is nothing, two lines is baby... Verona holds up both test sticks to the beam of the headlight. One stick shows one line, the other two. Burt grins.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Holy mother of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a quick montage of local landscapes -- mountains, trees, valleys, snow-capped peaks, ex-urban sprawl. This where our couple lives. The montage blends seamlessly into a new, strange kind of landscape. The sun is rising over a hill. It’s beautiful but also s and perhaps even eerie, given that the hill is caramel- colored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We back up a few inches and realize that the camera has l up so Verona’s belly -- 5 months pregnant -- looks like a small round mountain, and the sun appears to be rising be it. We hear vague sounds of scraping. Verona wakes up, turns over, sees Burt sitting up, with a knife and Verona is a piece of wood.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey. I’m glad you’re up.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What does it look like? I’m cobbling. in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I want to be a dad who knows how to carve stuff out of wood. I want our kid to get up in the morning and find me cobbling.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You're not cobbling.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I am cobbling. Look. I’ve got a knife and some wood and I’m making a toy... (looking at the shapeless blob of wood) «+. stick. I’m cobbling.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You’re not. That’s not what it’s called.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Of course it is. How would you know? You don’t have one of these. (indicating the knife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, cobbling is shoes. That’s why they're called cobblers. You're not cobbling. You’re carving. Burt thinks for a while. It dawns on him that she’s right This takes some of the appeal out of it for Burt. He stop carving. He rests his pathetic wooden worm/stick on Veron stomach.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Look, she likes it. I saw her kick.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I can do other things, too. I just bought a book about knots. 300 knots, and I’m gonna learn them all. And I’m gonna build a kiln. We've got to be ready! Verona goes into the bathroom. We follow her.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Remember we go to your parents’ house at noon. Be ready for that. Burt pops his head into the bathroom. He’s now wearing goggles and fatigues.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I pushed it back to 12:30. I’ve got that family-defense class today.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No, no, no. You’ve been so normal for the past few weeks...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I‘1l be back at noon. Might be later if we get into some hand-to- hand action. See you guys. He leans down to kiss Verona’s lips passionately and her stomach gently, and then walks out. We follow Burt out of the house, where we see that it’s a small ranch house, one step up from a trailer, attached t small grungy yard. He gets into a crumbling old Toyota an drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is in a class with a dozen other men, lined up in ne rows. The instructor is a Navy SEAL-type, also wearing goggles. Behind him are inflatable models of a wife and t small children. The wife is wearing a halter top and the children both have (real) iPods attached to them.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Will you be there to defend your family?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (in unison with the others) I will!

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Do you have the skills to prevent them from being taken from you, leaving you bereft and emasculated?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (in unison with the others) I do! With that, the instructor steps over to Burt and gives hi kick round-house kick to the side of the head. Burt goes down. We see the instructor from Burt’s perspective, hove over him, the inflatable family in the background.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Not yet you don’t. INT. HOUSE -- VERONA’S OFFICE/STUDIO -- MIDMORNING The sounds of huffing and puffing. We think for a second Verona’s exercising or in labor. But we turn the corner a see Verona sitting at her drafting table, brush in hand, working on a medical illustration. It’s a cramped and messy place -- illustration board, a drawing table, canvases, hundreds of markers and small pa containers. All over the walls are insane photos of peopl and animals in mid-surgery. Verona’s on the phone, looking at a TV in the corner, whe prenatal exercise video is playing. On screen, there are three women doing supra-geeky aerobic routines.  10. They look like they’re direct from 1986, with headbands a leg-warmers and poofy hair. The decor is ridiculous -- as they're exercising in a “Price Is Right” living room interior. The saddest thing is that this is a brand-new p natal fitness DVD.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I wish you could see this, Grace. We see Grace, Verona’s sister, on the other end of the ph GRACE is striking-looking: caramel-skinned, thin, curvy. She's immaculately dressed, projecting an air of sophistication and professionalism. She paces around her office at work -- a glass building in Phoenix, dramatic desert view -- with a hands-free device attached to her e

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You want to hear the rhyming couplets? Instead of reaching for a bagel Do another Kegel

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You like that? Jesus. Grace, tell me: Do I have to be uncool for the rest of my life?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? You’re talking to me while you're exercising?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No, I’m just watching it. I’ve got a cranial surgery thing due Friday. Trying to finish it before dinner at Burt’s parents tonight. We see that Verona is working on an illustration of a cra operation. The subject’s skin is peeled back, revealing t brain, and there’s a scalpel entering the subject’s front lobe via the nostril. It’s incredibly graphic, and Verona doing the work with incredible nonchalance -- she’s snack on cold lasagna set unsettling close to the open-brain illustration.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: They must be out of their minds excited.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You have no idea. (touching up part of the painting where a scalpel is inserted into the skull via the nostril) I think part of them is happy to be the only set of grandparents. To have the baby to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that. Grace looks at a photo of her and Verona’s parents, on he desk. In it, their parents are chasing the two girls -- 6 8 years old at the time -- in front of a big, funny old h in the country. In the picture, it’s winter, a bit bleak.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You’re so lucky to have them so close. Burt’s lucky to have them both still-- Now we see that Verona’s looking at the same picture of h parents in her studio.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I know, I know. That’s why we moved here. I think it’s just a matter of setting some boundaries. Lost in her thoughts, she lets her brush drift a bit.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh shit. I just gave this guy’s brain a vulva. INT. CAR -- DRIVING TO BURT’S PARENTS’ HOUSE Verona is driving. Burt is holding ice to his head.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So lame.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Forget it. (changing his mind) Wait. Tell me something. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURT (cont'd) Do I look like I can’t jump from a two-story building?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Wha-

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Just tell me that. Just... let’s Say you see me on the street, and you have to make a judgment: can that guy jump from a second-story building or not?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Burt—

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Please. I need this.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (seriously) Yes. I think you could do it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: See! But those fuckers were... Whatever. It doesn’t matter. They pass over a river. The landscape is wintery and spar

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I really want her to have an epic kind of childhood. I want her to run along the streams and to know how to work a canoe, and to be able to entertain herself when she’s outside. I want her childhood to be Huck Finny, you know?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I had that.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I know, that’s what I mean. I want her to have what you had.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Without it being in Arkansas.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Exactly. Burt’s cellphone rings.  13.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Burt Farlander. (listens) Oh you old so-and-so! Sorry about your Celtics, my friend. If you think Paul Pierce can carry more than a bucket of water, I have a bridge you might be interested in! Burt laughs uproariously. This entire time, he’s been speaking in the voice of a 50s radio announcer. Actually, sounds eerily like Casey Kasem, and it’s obvious that thi voice-change Burt uses for clients drives Verona around t bend.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Well thanks for calling back. I wanted to talk to you about hurricane season. I just.. No, I know you’re covered, but are you covered-covered? When it’s clear the call will go on for a few minutes, Ve pulls the car over on the highway and gets out, shutting Burt/Casey Kasem inside. Finally he motions to her that he’s almost done. She gets back inside.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (finishing up) Okay then. I will! I will! Ha ha. Yes. Yes. Oh please. You’re too much. Okay now. Talk to you soon. They drive for a few minutes in silence. Verona is contemplating divorce or murder.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: They expect that from me.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: They expect you to sound like Casey Kasem.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Listen, Rona, these guys are all in their fifties and sixties. We’re dealing with hundreds of millions of dollars in insurance futures. They don’t want to be dealing with some 31-year-old who didn’t finish college.  14. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: So Casey Kasem finished college? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yes. Silence for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Do you think your mom’s gonna grope me this time?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She always gropes you. She loves you. She wants to be you.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Ten bucks your dad says I look glorious.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Listen. He spent 18 months in prison, Rone--

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: White collar prison. They live better than we do.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: And now everything is glorious for him. The English muffins are glorious. The margarine is glorious. I gave him my old sandals, and those were “spectacular.” But the baby is really important to them. Now that they’re retired and I really think they’re gonna build their world around little Zeus.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s a girl. Her name isn’t Zeus.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (with purpose) Jesus, Rona. Think about it: Zeus. Excelsior. Farlander. Zeus Farlander. That’s the name of a girl of ... of...  15.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Destiny?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Thank you. A girl of destiny. INT. PARENTS’ HOME It’s a very clean upper-middle-class home, a bit on the overwrought side -- lots of figurines and glass and mirro The door bursts open as Burt and Verona walk up the steps see GLENDA, who is about 60, very fit, wearing a jean jac with a faux-fur collar, turned up. She has very short whi hair, cut in that severe style favored by many women her Inexplicably, she’s also wearing a headband.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: (to Verona) Oh! Look at you! You look so big. Good for you!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Your hair. What'd you do?

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: I cut it!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: And the headband.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: I know! I know! Come in, your dad’s inside. In the front hall, Burt stops upon a large fountain. It s to be a sculpture of a colonial pilgrim pumping water fro tap into some kind of earthenware, held by a Native Ameri woman. Both are smiling gravely. In the living room, Glenda is already sitting on the couc patting the cushion next to her.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Sit, Verona. Sit next to me and let me hear the heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You can’t hear her heartbeat. The placenta’s on this side-- Verona sits, trying to indicate that the placenta is on t outside, and thus muffles the sound of the heartbeat...  16. Too late. Glenda has already arranged her head on Verona’ stomach. She has one hand on Verona’s thigh and the other between her breasts and stomach. It’s very intimate. Vero would be horrified if she were surprised, but she isn’t. JIM, Burt’s father, enters the room. He is 65, handsome, successful, with hair longer than Glenda’s, and is limpin self-made man, he grew up poor but cultivates an air of incredible suaveness.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Hey Jim! You're looking so much better! You can barely see where you broke it.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Thank you my dear. Verona, you look glorious. Verona smiles at Burt.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Did you bring the pictures from the sonogram?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We did. Verona tries to get up but Glenda is burrowed into her so deeply that she can't move.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I'll get them. Burt removes an envelope from Verona's purse. He starts t hand it to Glenda, but she’s so busy groping Verona that changes course and instead hands the envelope to Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: These are fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You haven't opened the envelope yet.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I can just tell. He’s a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It's a girl. (to Burt) Did --  17.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I told you that, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: She's a beauty. Jim finally opens the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Wow. Spectacular. Exquisite. Glenda is now laying in Verona's lap.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Jim, do you want your glasses?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Love. Jim, struggling without his glasses, is looking at the pictures judiciously, like a doctor examining an X-ray. W cut to a shot of the sonogram, which is horrifying. A straight-on picture of the baby’s face, it looks almost precisely like the skull of an alien with vast ocular cavities and a row of fangs.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Talk about perfection!

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: So, how dark do you think she'll be?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: No, really. Jim and I were kind of disappointed when Burt’s brother Courtney married that white woman. Glenda indicates a wedding picture on the nearby end tabl of Courtney -- shaggy and appealing -- next to a fake-smi woman with what seem to be breast implants bursting from low-cut wedding dress.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Helena. Glenda rolls her eyes at the name. + eH  18.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Jim and I think it would be wonderful to have an African granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Glenda, the correct terminology is African-American. It will be wonderful to have a granddaughter of African-American persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Forget the semantics. We're all family. Verona, how black do you think she'll be?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (looking to Burt for help) Uh, I don't really know...

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Because you know she won't be very dark at first. It takes a while for the pigment to settle in.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe we could leave her out in the sun for the first couple of days... Glenda and Jim look at each other like this might be a va option. A judicious look overtakes Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Verona, are you on schedule? Jim pronounces the word “shheduuel.”

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Don’t ask her that. Verona, we’re just concerned about your tilted uterus... Verona shoots dagger-eyes at Burt. He looks very surprise that his mom remembered this detail.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Do you think that might present problems during delivery?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay, that's enough. (changing the subject) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURT (cont'd) So we've been reading all these books, trying to decide what kind of birthing experience we want to have...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That's terrific.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: -..and we think we want to limit the amount of people in the room. Or near the room.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Oh you don’t have to worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Right. No sweat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: And we decided that we don’t want any videotaping.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Right. I won’t. Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But we really want you to share this with us. Your presence is really important.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: You are so right. We're so looking forward to it. We will definitely be there.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And the only reason we won't be there is if we’re living in Belgium. Burt and Verona are dumbstruck. They have no idea what Ji talking about.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: (sitting forward now and grinning maniacally) We have news.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It’s big.  20.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: We're leaving in June.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: We're finally doing it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You're leaving in June? The baby’s due in July.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Right. To Antwerp. City of Light.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That’s not--. No you’re not.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: We are. It going to be superb.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Don’t say that word.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: We thought you'd be proud of us. We've been talking about this for fifteen years and now we can finally do it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You're leaving a month before the baby’s born? You’re moving 3000 miles away from your grandchild?

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: It’s more than 3000 miles, isn’t it, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: There are planes, Burt.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This is what we’ve been planning to do forever, son. You know that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM (cont'd) We'll make a fortune if we can declare residency over there.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How long will you be gone?

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: Just two years.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Are you selling the house?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Well, that’s the best part. We were going to rent out the house, with the help of a very handsome gentleman named Fareed. But no one’s come forward yet--

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How long have you planned this? Has our house-- At that moment, Burt sees, on the coffee table, a large a the paper offering the house he grew up in, for rent.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It’s just been running since Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: We heard from your old gym teacher! He came here with another man. They were both wearing... (gesturing up and down her leg to indicate stripes) ++. running suits. This news is doubly disturbing to Burt.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDA
dialogues.text: But if we don’t get a renter in the next month, you guys can stay here while we're gone. You can have the house for the next two years! Jim is gesturing around him, as if showing the house to h son for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Outstanding.  22. Verona looks impressed with this idea. Burt, too, softens They share a brief day-dream of their daughter running through the house, playing on the immaculate lawn, swimmi in the pool. The idea grows on them by the minute. The phone rings, shaking them from their reverie. Glenda goes to the kitchen to answer it. We hear Glenda’s excited voice off-screen. Meanwhile, Burt and Verona noti an unfamiliar sculpture in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That new? It’s a bronze sculpture of a young Native American woman, wearing little more than a cowhide bikini, raising her ar to the sky, nipples insanely erect.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Magnificent, isn’t it? I was wondering when you’d notice. Twelve thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I know! She’s a Choctaw princess, I’m told. (nodding seriously) It’s important that we honor our Indian... Our indigent ... our indigentous people. Glenda returns, barely able to contain her excitement.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Was it Fareed? Glenda nods.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Did he....? Glenda nods quickly, barely containing her euphoria.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (turning to Burt and Verona) Well, it looks like we have some more news for you two.

dialogues.speaker: IN CAR
dialogues.text: They're driving home from Glenda and Jim’s house.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: They’re very strange people. I always forget how strange they are. Burt is fuming.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We can get different grandparents. The second they said “Belgium” I started thinking of ways to hurt them. We’1ll make someone else the grandparents. Our neighbors. What're their names?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: They look old enough. We can give them nicknames and tell the baby that those are the grandparents. The baby won't know the difference.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It really is an awful thing to do. They knew we moved here for them. I mean, we’ve only been here for a year and now... They’1ll miss the baby’s first two years. It sort of takes selfishness to a new level. This crosses a line with Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’s not like your parents are doing anything.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: My parents are dead, Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Still... They drive in silence for a minute.  24. INT. BURT AND VERONA’S HOUSE --NIGHT Verona enters, Burt close behind. She stops after enterin as if seeing their sad little home with new eyes. It’s clearly freezing inside.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I can see my breath.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I'll get the thing. Burt pulls a space heater out from under Verona’s desk. T second he plugs it in, the lights go out; he’s blown a fu The house is in total darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’1ll get the candles. The opening of drawers. A match is struck. This outtage i routine. Now we see them in candlelight. The conversation continues as they get candles lit all over their small ho

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing keeping us here.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (busy with the candles) Huh.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? We could leave, too.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (still not paying attention) Right.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Burt. I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Fine. Where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Anywhere. We don’t have to live here. We can live wherever we want. I can do my job anywhere, and all you need is a phone, right? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERONA (cont'd) The only reason we’re here is because your parents are here -- or were here.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We don’t want to go back to Chicago, do we? We did Chicago. And don’t say Belgium. Verona hadn’t thought this far.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Now Burt is excited by the idea. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We could go to Idaho. Fishing and everything. Lots of land. Idaho!

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Lots of Aryans.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Not lots. Some. And they’re all in that one town. It’s better that way -- we know where they are. Like ... druids and... Stonehenge.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What about Phoenix? We could live near my sister. Think of that! Oh, that would make me so happy. And Lily and Sam live there.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (almost remembering) Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You met at their going-away party. At the arcade.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Good party.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: They can be our friends in Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But they weren’t our friends here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: But they can be in Phoenix. They can be our new good friends when we live in Phoenix. They sit for a moment, now surrounded by candles. The sce is oddly beautiful and romantic.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We won’t need a space heater in Phoenix...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the snakes... And all that turquoise...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (holding her from behind, his arms draped over her and rubbing her stomach) Wherever we go, Rona, I will protect you. From the cold. (kisses her neck) From the dark. (kisses it again) From the snakes. (once again) From the turquoise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona and Burt are waiting for the doctor to come in. Bu is playing with the stirrups.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don't want you on that side when the doctor's examining me.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Because you’re not a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (examining some instruments in the cabinet) Rona, the only thing they’ve got that I don’t is the nine years of schooling. +e %

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. HILL knocks on door and enters. She is young, blond, a kind face and bad jewelry. Burt is displaying his hands wearing Dr. Hill’s rubber gloves. She stares at the hands deeply confused.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Verona? Dr. Hill speaks in a slow whisper, as if she’s mixing her meds.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I'm good.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Nothing surprising?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No, everything’s pretty predictable. I'll get a mole and then look in the pregnancy book under “moles” and it’1ll say “At this point you may be getting moles...” A snap draws Dr. Hill’s attention to Burt. He’s just fini putting on rubber gloves, as if he and Dr. Hill will be performing the exam together.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: This is Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m the husband.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: He’s not my husband.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m the father. Dr. Hill looks to Verona to confirm this, which she does an almost reluctant closing of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: (putting on gloves) Okay. I'd like to listen to baby's heartbeat and see if it's as... (she hesitates, searching for the right word) relaxed as it was last time.  28. Dr. Hill smooths gel on Verona's stomach and uses a Doppl to listen to the baby. We hear the sounds of the heartbea Verona smiles. Burt smiles. Dr. Hill frowns.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: It's still on the slow side. I don't think it's anything to worry about. Baby’s just...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s a girl.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: She's just a little mellow.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (his face lighting up) Could it mean she's an athlete? Athletes have slow heartbeats.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: (dismissively) No. It’s probably a bit soon to know if she’ll be playing sports. (turning to Verona) Um... I'm going to do a quick exam down there. Burt switches positions so he’s standing near Verona’s he

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to Dr. Hill) She hasn't been able to shave. She can’t see down there and she won’t let me do it. But it’s a thicket, right? You almost expect thorns, blackberries--

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: (proceeding with the exam, ignoring Burt) Well, your uterus has expanded, so it's no longer tilted. Verona gives Burt a triumphant look.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Everything else there is looking good. Nice job.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Thanks.  29.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (now taking off the rubber gloves) Thanks. Dr. Hill deposits her gloves in the garbage, and Burt doe too, as if together they’ve just finished surgery.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: (suddenly wistful) You're really, really lucky. Verona and Burt recognize that Dr. Hill has things on her mind. There’s a long awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What about traveling? Is there any reason I can’t get on a plane?

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Don’t say Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. Phoenix. And a few other places.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We're looking for a new place to live.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Wow. That sounds nice. To get away. To keep going. Like a quest... Dr. Hill says the word like a Tolkein wizard would, while staring at the walls. Instead of medical charts or cheerf pictures, there’s a large self-portrait Dr. Hill has done It’s insanely depressing, seemingly painted with mud and

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Are you videotaping?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: (pointing to Verona’s stomach) The stages? Your growth?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Not yet. a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. I will. Burt has just found a new hobby.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: You seem really happy, Verona.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I am. I do feel happy. Sort of exuberant.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: (saying the word like it’s completely foreign) Exuberant. (thinking on it) Well, be prepared. After birth, a lot of people -- a lot of my patients at least -- experience a severe depression after giving birth. There’s the usual baby blues, but then there’s the real deal. It’ll drag you through the clouds till you can’t see the sun. Burt and Verona begin feeling depressed, then and there.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Just let me know and I can write you a prescription. Most of my patients are on Zoloft and they ... love ... it. (she takes a pad and rips off the top page; it’s pre-written -- she gives the same drugs to everyone) Actually, here’s a script just in case. She pauses a moment, staring into the eyes of her self- portrait.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HILL
dialogues.text: Just keep the end result in mind. When you have your baby, it’1l be just great. 30. There is no way Dr. Hill, or anyone, could have said this a less convincing way.  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are sitting at the gate. They look not un Dustin Hoffman and Katharine Ross at the end of The Gradu they’ve made a big decision and now are very unsure about

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Now I’m wondering what we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We're going to Phoenix. On an airplane. This is where they keep the airplanes.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But in general. Are we nuts?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We’ll look around. See if we could live there. We agree we need to be near some kind of family, some friends -- something, some connection, someone we know. So we'll see Phoenix, see my sister--

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: .+. and our new closest friends... Burt can’t remember their names. He still has no idea who these people are.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Lily and Sam. And then we go to Hartford for your job interview.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: My what?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Oh god. Your interview. You're meeting with Providential Life to see if they’1l give you a better commission. You set it up. Verona removes a small plastic bag full of pre-cut carrot from her bag. She eats them as they continue talking.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So then from Hartford we go home?  32.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. Did you look at the itinerary? I stapled it to your jacket. (Burt locates it -- it’s actually stapled to the inside of his jacket) We go from Hartford to Montreal. Montreal’s where I think we should live if we don’t live in Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay. Montreal.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: This is exciting, if you think about it. We’re completely untethered, Burt -- this is a dream scenario!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah! They sit for a long, awkward moment. It’s not particularl dreamy. Verona keeps eating her carrots. In front of them, the DEPARTURES lists dozens of destinations, from Houston to London to Mexico City.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Then again, it seems weird, to just decide on a place and move there.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: C'mon! How did the pioneers do it, Rona? They just spun that globe, picked a spot because there was gold there, or ... wheat ... and then the whole family got moving, in their covered wagons and with their horses and oxen. They traveled through rain and sleet, over mountains and plains, and then three-fourths of them died on the way. We’re just following in their footsteps, honey. Burt lunges for a kiss, and they do, open-mouthed, until pulls away. Burt spits out a mouthful of carrots. Now Verona begins hacking the carrot shrapnel from her throat. Carrots all the airport carpet.  33. A dozen people are watching them. Verona and Burt are use this. Their mouths carrot-free, they go back to making ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're parked at a 7-11. Verona is in the driver’s seat the rental car while Burt is inside the store. Verona is on the phone with Lily.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Sure... That sounds fun. We’ll get there. No problem. Burt is still in the store, trying on a visor that says PHOENIX IS PHANTASTIC. Now he’s holding two bottles of wi up to the glass for Verona’s approval. She points to the on the left.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’‘ll be good to see you, too. What? Of course I can walk. I’m only six months! What? No. No. Not much. Okay. See you there. Burt emerges from the store with the wine. To comment on incredible heat of Phoenix, he is walking in slow-motion, if swimming through molasses. By the time he’s near the c he’s on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (to Burt, who is now laying beside the car) Lordy. I forgot about Lily’s mouth. She’s a good person -- I mean, the best when you’re really in trouble - - but the shit that comes out of her mouth...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (still laying on the pavement) Like what?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She just asked if my discharge smelled like broccoli.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (curious) Huh. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURT (cont'd) (beat) Does it?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Just... (dropping the subject) You think we can bring wine to a dog track?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (still laying on the pavement) Chardonnay? Sure. (realizing what she’s actually asking) Wait. Are we going to a dog track?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hold on. He goes back into the 7-11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona and Burt -- who is now wearing the PHOENIX IS PHANTASTIC visor -- get out of the car and wander through complex. At the fence near the track, they find LILY and with their two children. LILY is 40, average-looking, a b matronly, wearing red cowboy boots which someone has told look sexy. SAM is rigid, with a mustache and short, gelle hair. He wears a button-down shirt and shorts that are a too small. Their children are ASHLEY, 10 years old and a tomboy, and TAYLOR, 6 years old and on the pudgy side. He wearing a shirt that also says PHOENIX IS PHANTASTIC. Lily is turning to tuck in Taylor’s shirt when she sees B and Verona.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (rushing toward Verona) Oh god, look at you! You’re only six months in! Jesus, you're huge. And your face! It’s like you’re half Chinese. Wow. Come here and give us a hug! Sam, come give a hug to the most beautiful woman in the world! Sam walks over. Lily sees something in Sam’s face that indicates he has no idea who these people are.  35.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Verona and I were desk buddies in Chicago! At the agency! That was before she broke out on her own... (to Verona) I still have no idea where you learned how to paint the insides of dead people. So fucking disgusting, girlfriend! (now to Burt) She’s so talented! Our little artiste! Sam is still fuzzy.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You met them at our going away party. At the arcade. Now Sam remembers. Almost.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Good party. Sam gives Verona an awkward hug and shakes Burt’s hand. H holding a half-full plastic cup of white wine. He sees th bottle of wine in Burt’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh good. (taking the bottle) I was almost out. Can I get you guys something?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Water.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Beer would be good. Sam gulps the contents of his plastic cup, chucks it into garbage and walks toward the concession stand. Taylor is sitting on the ground, holding a Crayola marker a racing form, circling the dogs he thinks will win. Ashl is standing against the fence, watching the action on the track, wishing she were living a different life.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: So you're in Arizona! You're Arizonans! I can’t believe how big the kids are. Taylor’s so handsome!  36.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (laughs skeptically) Well, thanks. We’re gonna do something about the ears. You see them? He looks like a trophy. You know what I mean, one of those trophies with the arms on it? Lily is finding herself hugely amusing. She has been told few times that she should do stand-up comedy, and in her she’s constantly testing out her material. Lily now turns her attention to Ashley.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: This one has that dyke look. (wrinkling her nose) Doesn't she? Isn’t that weird? She’s only ten but I’m sure she’s a dyke. She’s gonna be a point guard for the WNBA. Aren’t they all lesbians? I think that’s weird, how the lesbians sort of rule that whole sport. Walk for Verona, Ashley. Show us your tough-girl walk. Go butch on us. Ashley doesn’t move or turn around.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Oh now she’s shy. And look at her ass -- she’s got... what is it, Sam? Junk in the trunk? She’s got junk in her trunk. I don’t know if the dykes go for that or not. Burt, you worked with a dyke, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (whispering -- not wanting the kids to hear more of the conversation) Yes, I--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (louder, defiant) I can’t hear you.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (now in a louder whisper) I just ... don’t know if we should be talking like this in front of the kids.  37.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Oh god. It’s just white noise to them. We see the kids for a second, and it’s clear that they’re hearing every word. Sam has returned with the drinks, and a corkscrew for the wine.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (holding the corkscrew, indicating the concession- stand workers) Those bastards didn’t want to give me this. Fuck those motherfuckers. Redneck pieces of redneck shit. Burt is taken aback. Sam switches back to perfect congeniality.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What’s your line again, Burt? Lily was telling me but it was all gibberish coming from her. Burt takes a swig of his beer and seems very thankful for He and Sam take a few steps toward the track -- having th own conversation while Verona and Lily have theirs.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’s not that complicated, really. I trade insurance futures. Just like you get insurance, insurance companies need it themselves...

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Dammit, right! Shit. Of course it would come to this. Sam is speaking in an urgent whisper, as if he’s finally figured it all out.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: They made us afraid of everything. Insurance for insurance for insurance. Bunkers and bubbles and .»+. aw hell. This country is shit. Shit shit shit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM (cont'd) But everyone else in the world is just the flies on our shit, am I right? Burt has nothing to say. On the track, there is a brief ceremony saluting the soldiers killed in Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Watch the big one, number 8. I’ve got eight bills on him to place. Sam pats Burt on the back and throws a steely-eyed glare across the greyhound track.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (throwing her voice over from the conversation she’s having with Verona) Hey Sam, I used to have boobs, right? Verona doesn’t remember, I don't think. I had nice tits, right? (indicating her kids) They sucked me dry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: This is correct. I married a busty woman, and now--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Now they look like rolls of quarters stuck into two thin socks. Are you ready for that, Burt? I can tell you’re probably a boob-man. Burt forces a weak chuckle. The dog race ends.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ah shit. (to Burt) Looks like dinner’s on you. Sam downs his wine.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: So Burt, you excited about all this? Burt thinks she means the dog track.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is the best one I’ve seen, I think. He looks around approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, the baby, dummy. Does this mean you guys will finally get married?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to Lily) They're not married?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I told you that. Burt wants to, but Verona doesn’t see the point.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The point? Insurance, for one. If anyone, you should understand that, Bart. Does anyone ever call you Bart? That’d be sort of funny.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, we didn’t have insurance when Ashley was born.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: We thought we did and then we didn’t. And I couldn't get it -- pre-existing condition. Burt and Verona are expected to know what this condition but they don’t. She twirls her finger around her ear.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I'm crazy. A wild giggle escapes her mouth.  40.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (pointing to Ashley with his thumb) That girl cost us $24,000. Had to borrow from every relative we were still speaking to.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Every time she’s acting up or whatever, you can’t help thinking, “We shelled out 24-thou for this?” Lily lets out a cackle. She thinks she’s hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (laying a hand on Ashley’s shoulder) You know I’m kidding, honey. Ashley wants to disappear.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I just don’t think the certificate and a huge wedding will change the way we feel about each other.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: At the very least, it’1l keep you from taking off in the middle of the night when there’s trouble. Sam is nodding vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I almost left Sam about a dozen times. The kids don’t know that. The kids, of course, are right in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But then you start thinking of the wedding, all that money--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (pouring himself another full cup of chardonnay) $46,000 for ours. It was worth maybe $31.  41.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (sighing) I hope you guys move here. We’re having a hell of a time getting into the social world here. Seems very cliquish. Or maybe it’s something about Sam they don’t like. I don’t know what it is. We didn’t get into the good golf club.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Run by a Pakistani couple! How do you like that? My family goes back to the Santa Maria. I get turned down by a Paki named Taqi. Lily and Sam are greatly amused by this, though it’s clea he’s used this anecdote a few dozen times.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You really think you might come down here?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (looking around, as if judging the liveability of Phoenix based on the dog track) Well...

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Okay, it’s not perfect. But what is? No place is perfect, just like no marriage is perfect. Sam and I have both had... (searching for an appropriate word) dalliances, and we're still plugging away. Good as ever. But families are fucked up. They’re created that way. There’s no way around it, so there’s no use pretending it can be all roses and love and that shit.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (gushing, utterly sincere) Well, that was wonderful.  42. Sam walks by, throws the bottle of wine, now empty, loudl into the garbage can, and heads into the parking lot to f the car. The kids shuffle after him. He says nothing to B and Verona -- he’s either too drunk or has forgotten them completely.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You know, people will offer all sorts of advice to you, but whatever you do, don’t listen to any of it. Kids are resilient -- and they're genetically predetermined anyway. They’1ll be fine no matter what. Ashley has wandered off and is leaning into the window of pickup truck -- talking to two middle-aged cowboys. Taylo nearby, picking gum off the hot cement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are sitting on deck chairs by the pool, positioned side-by-side, very much like sunbathers. It’s about 9 o’clock and quite dark.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You think that’s right, that all families are inherently screwed up, that we can’t hope for any kind of normal happiness?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t. Beat. The sound of crickets.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Wait. You don’t what? You don’t think it’s possible, or you don’t agree with her?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You know I don’t agree, Burt. I hate that attitude -- “Everything's broken so let’s (putting her feet on the ground and stomping, as if crushing the shards of a vase into dust) break everything again and again and again.”  43.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But you’re the one who won’t get married. If you’re so optimistic...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: But it’s beside the point! I’m saying we can be perfect, we can be happy, and it doesn’t have anything to do with paper titles or a ring or a $42,000 wedding-- Was it

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It was, but it was only worth $31. They chuckle and stare into the starry sky.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Did you hear what Lily was saying about her boobs? Did you know her when she had boobs?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She was huge. This is very disturbing news to Burt. He hadn’t thought o this, and would miss Verona’s medium-sized chest.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are moving about the room, unpacking and changing into their sleep clothes.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So how do you prevent that? You don’t wanna go flat, do you?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No, but I don’t know how much control I have over it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Was your mom... Did she breastfeed you guys?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She died when I was twenty-four. I didn’t get around to asking her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are laying in bed. Burt is rubbing stretc mark cream on Verona’s stomach and hips. It’s a delicate moment, but Burt can’t leave the subject alone. He jumps up and grabs Verona’s wallet and finds her pictu of her parents.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Did your mom have... I can’t tell from these...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She looked like me, Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: After she had you guys, too? Burt is beginning to brighten.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes. Now Burt realizes he shouldn’t be grinning about the size Verona’s dead mother’s breasts. He takes a more studious approach.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But she might not have breast-fed you guys...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Please, Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most interest you've ever shown in my mother, and it’s about her boobs. It’s making me not like you.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I just think we need to do the research. I think we need to know what kind of strategies there might be. I mean, I see plenty of older women who still have their boobs. So there must be a way to keep them. You like your boobs, right?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So you’d want to keep them if you could...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Good. So I’'ll do the research. I’1l figure out what it takes. I’m sure there are some guidelines. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Some tricks. Together we'll do this. I’1l do this. For you.
Burt and Verona are laying in bed, spooning, each looking the window at the pulsing highway beyond.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I have good news.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What? Burt turns onto his back and stares at the ceiling, folded across his chest. his hands  46.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I decided wood-carving is just as good as cobbling. (now whispering, with much gravitas) Our daughter's father will be a wood-carver. He puts his leg over hers. She reaches back, grabbing his ass, and pulls him closer. They drift off to sleep. INT. CAR -- DRIVING TO SISTER’S HOTEL Burt and Verona are driving to meet her sister, Grace. Gr works as a concierge at a very high-end hotel in Phoenix. Burt is driving, and this is a problem. He tends to push accelerator down in bursts, making anyone in his vehicle seasick.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: This is why I don’t let you drive.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Tell me one more time why we’re not staying at the hotel where your sister works?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: They’ve been booked for year. A conference of Belgians who now live in the southwest.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No. Belgians? As Burt pulls the car into the hotel parking lot, he sees three men, perhaps Belgian, walking on the sidewalk. He h angrily.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What the fuck with the Belgians all of a sudden? For thirty-three years I have no interaction with Belgians and now they’re fucking up every aspect of my life. Burt honks at another group of Belgians, this batch inclu some children. They look startled and utterly innocent. Burt parks the car. Verona adjusts her dress over her bel and turns to Burt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Grace has been dating some guy named Rob, who seems nice but she thinks he’s boring. He likes going to steakhouses, that kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Wait, was that a good thing, or a bad thing, the steakhouses?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Bad.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Like an Outback Steakhouse? Ruth’s Chris Steak House?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I honestly don’t know. But we need to make him seem cool. She likes you, Burt. She’1l value your endorsement of this guy. They get out of the car and make their way through the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So you want me to make steakhouses sound cool?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: And sherbet.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No. Not sherbet.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Apparently Rob’s family lives around here and they had her over for dinner. They served sherbet. (registering Burt’s confusion) Instead of sorbet. This was a big deal for Grace. It made her sad. Burt is still at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We just need to make him seem like a good, decent man. And also an exciting sort of guy. I don’t know. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERONA (cont'd) We'll figure it out. And don’t look at her tits.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m over it. I was good last time.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: But she’s bigger now. She went on the pill and now she’s complaining about getting new bras and everything. Burt's eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Huh.... There’s a long pause, where Burt tries to figure out the way to make his suggestion, and while it dawns on Verona he’s about to say what he’s about to say.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Why don’t you go on the pill?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant, moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While waiting for Grace, Verona and Burt see a MOM with h two kids, 5 and eighteen months. The mother, white, is talking to her kids very loudly, as if everyone nearby sh be interested in hearing what she says to her children -- all aspects of her fascinating child-rearing.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Yes, Martin Luther! That’s a fern! Burt and Verona keep watching. Verona is getting annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s a cactus. And the plural of cactus is...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER
dialogues.text: Cacti?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: That's right! Oh Amelie, you've dribbled on your new French dress!  49. The mom looks around, expecting everyone in the vicinity smile at the wonder of childhood and her spectacular litt family. She finds only Verona, staring her down with a lo of unmitigated disgust.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (to Burt, between her teeth) Performance moms. Nothing goes un- narrated.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: There’s Grace. Grace is saying goodbye to a group of Belgians. She sends them onto their tour bus and turns to see Verona and Burt

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Wow, look at you! Finally showing! You are radiant! Luminous! Effervescent! Hey Burt! She gives Burt a quick but very tight hug. She and Verona think nothing of it, but Burt is in a momentary daze.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You guys want to eat here, or go out...?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We don’t want to go out there... for a while. Feels like we’re being cooked.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s hot.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No, I mean truly. Think about it. If you were actually being cooked by someone, that’s what it would feel like. As if God had formed us from clay, but it was the kind of clay you needed to bake, as opposed to the kind you just leave out to dry.  50.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (meaning it) Wow, Burt. That is so stoney!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Well, it’s the Bible. QED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-conversation:

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Two days ago he asked me if I like movies. Like movies are something some people don’t like. He actually posed the question like it was some great conversation-starter. (imitating his voice) “Do you like movies?” (looking into her salad) It was painful.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I wish someone would ask me that sometime. That’s a probing sort of intelligence, I think.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He doesn’t assume the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But the way he dresses! He wears basketball jerseys without any shirt underneath.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’s Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But he’s so white!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Is he buff?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Most basketball players aren’t. Or they didn’t use to be. You ever see the Celtics from the 70s? They were mostly white and not very buff. Is this guy from Boston?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I think his family is from Boston.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: He drives a Cabriolet.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Great design. Good mileage.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: He uses the word “robust.”

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Lots of things are robust!

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: He took me to Long John Silver's.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to Verona) I thought you said it was a steakhouse.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: When I told him I didn’t want the steakhouse, he took me to Long John Silver's.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He’s being sensitive to your needs and desires. You say no turf, he goes surf. He’s a quick thinker.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But every time I have an issue with something, he just accommodates me. I tell him not to wear bleached jeans and he doesn’t wear them. I think he read somewhere that he’s supposed to laugh at my jokes, so for a week he would literally double-over every time I made an attempt. Like this: (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRACE (cont'd) (she demonstrates by throwing her head forward) You know, like even when he was driving. I had to ask him to stop. Verona gives Burt a look, like he needs to step up for Ro

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: This guy seems like a goddamned champ, Grace. He seems awesome. I’d marry him if it wasn’t against the law here. Grace now sees through the gambit. Verona gives Burt a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’ll get the check. Burt leaves the table and walks to the front desk. seconds, he’s talking to the woman there, older and with sizable chest.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Look at him. We’re having a baby that might have three feet or one eye and the thing he’s most worried about is whether or not I‘’1ll keep my boobs.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I think that’s sexy. Burt returns. He winks at Verona, like he’s got news for later.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So I’m meeting Rob at the driving range?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hey thanks, Burt. It means a lot to me. Just... get a feel for him. (mock-dramatically) Tell me if I can be as happy with him as Rona is with you. Young Martin Luther, son of the Performance Mom, has appe at their table.  53.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: (pointing to Verona’s stomach) Baby!

dialogues.speaker: PERFORMANCE MOM
dialogues.text: (delighted) Right, Martin Luther! This woman is about to have a baby -- any day now!

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Or in three months. (giving the mom a fake smile) Thank you. The kid is still at Verona’s side, inspecting her. The Performance Mom thinks she has an audience and is thus mo delighted than ever.

dialogues.speaker: PERFORMANCE MOM
dialogues.text: Martin Luther, tell the pretty lady what you know about babies. The boy says nothing. He’s frozen up.

dialogues.speaker: PERFORMANCE MOM
dialogues.text: C’mon, tell the nice people. The boy directs a malevolent look at his baby sister.

dialogues.speaker: PERFORMANCE MOM
dialogues.text: Martin. You’re being rude--

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: (still staring at his sister) Babies like to breathe and are good at hiding it. I put a pillow over a baby and I thought she wasn’t breathing but then she was. She was sneaky. She was breathing the whole time. But I’1l try again. Ashen-faced, the Performance Mom and her kids leave. Burt’s phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m gonna take this on the way to meeting Rob. I’1l see you guys later.  54. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (on phone, in loud, Casey Kasem voice) Ned! I can’t believe you're not hiding under a rock with the way your Titans played last Sunday! Ha ha ha... What? Yes siree I had money on it! Grace wistfully watches him walk away.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You got lucky, sister. Verona ponders this for a second. She’s inclined to cut t compliment with self-deprecating humor, but she refrains.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona and Grace are walking through the aisles, touching bathtubs and fixtures. This is a high-end showroom for decorators, and people with a lot of disposable income.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: So what would you think if we moved here? You could be Auntie Grace all the time. We could drive Burt crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I would love it, Rone. You have no idea. But I don’t know if I’m here for the long haul.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: But you’re looking at seven- thousand-dollar tubs!

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I can sell my house for twice what I paid for it. I can live five years off the profit. So... I just might do that. I don’t know. And I wouldn’t want you moving all the way here just to see me leave. They walk through the showroom.  55.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s strange how we live, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You’re younger than me, you're single, and you live in a 4,000- square-foot house. Burt and I are having a baby and we rent a three- room ranch.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s only because I try when it comes to money, Rone. You have your head in other places. I’m always going to be good at making money because I like making money. Why? Because I’m good at it. I don’t have a talent like you do.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: My talent is drawing people's organs. I wouldn’t glamorize it too much.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Get in. Grace is sitting inside a large white tub set atop giant feet.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t need to get in. It’s a nice tub. (now really looking at it, noticing something) Looks like the one we used to have at home.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Come on. I’1l pretend to wash your hair. Verona sheepishly steps into the tub and sits with her ba to Grace. Grace takes her hair into her hands and kneads pretending to lather shampoo into it.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: When was the last time you went back?  56.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Home? I haven’t. Not for ... a while. When are you gonna sell that place, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You mean when are we going to sell * it?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I told you I don’t want anything to do with it. You did the estate sale, you sell the house, too.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I feel funny selling it at the prices they’re offering. I’m going to wait -- I have a feeling the neighborhood's going to turn around. Just need some families to come back. +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s weird to think the baby won't have grandparents from our side.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It hits you again when these things come up. When there are places they should be but can’t be.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ah ha.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Now I know why you won’t marry that good man.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: That’s not it.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to have Uncle Mark or someone else walking you down the aisle...  57.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s not--

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: And giving you away! That would be sad, I guess. I can understand that. I’m not looking forward to it myself. Maybe I’1l elope... Verona’s eyes are wet, but Grace can’t see this. They sit silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s not good to think about.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No, it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Let's go. Grace steps out of the tub and then offers Verona a hand Verona struggles but gets herself up and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona is on the floor, doing pre-natal yoga stretches. B bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That was the most boring afternoon of my life. He throws himself against the wall, as if shipwrecked and finally finding dry land.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It’s hard to explain. He was wearing Dockers. Everywhere -- on his legs, on his head, his feet...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Thanks for not saying anything to Grace.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He had a Dockers shirt, a Dockers phone holster...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, honey.  58.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I can’t figure out how a guy can be that boring. Even while he was boring me, I thought maybe I could study it, like, be interested in how boring he was. But even that failed. I was bored by being bored by him. It was unprecedented.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Well, I know she probably won't stay with this guy, but at least we might ween her off the bad boys. Since high school all she wants is the bad boys. Even the guy she was engaged to was a bad boy.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: The florist?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: The florist from Japan was a bad boy?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: He was really rebellious.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What... Too much baby’s breath? That kind of thing? Verona is struggling to get off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I’m so tired of being big. Burt helps her up.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I’m tired of not having sex.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Do you want to have sex?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. Burt stares blankly.  59.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We haven’t had sex in a month.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But you don’t want to have it now.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We had sex last week.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. You came on my boobs.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. (quickly losing himself in a reverie)

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It‘’‘ll be months before I get my shape back.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So we don’t have sex for a while. I was prepared for that. This is one of those dips we go through. There are periods when you don’t have sex, Rone. I mean, what if I got into a horrible boating accident, and was covered in third-degree burns on most of my body? We’d do without sex then, right? Verona can’t believe this. She grabs the ice bucket and h to the door. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant, Burt. You didn’t get in a boating accident. And how do you get burns in a boating accident? (opening the door) We don’t even HAVE a boat.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah but-- She closes the door on him. Relief. We follow her all the down the hall, in utter silence. She savors the quiet, th respite from Burt’s mouth.  60. She gets the ice, and when returning, slows down as she c upon the door, almost knowing that as soon she opens it, he’1l begin again -- as if the conversation had never pau She takes a breath. She opens the door. She was right.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Funny you mentioned not having a boat. I meant to talk to you about that. I want the baby to grow up knowing the joys of the high seas. I want to raise her on the water. I want the salt water running through her veins! Verona throws herself onto the bed and buries her face in pillow. Burt misinterprets this as a sign that she’s stil upset about being big.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Rona? C’mon. Don’t be sad. You’re not that big. And you’re still super-sexy. Hot even. She buries her face deeper.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh honey. I’11 always love you, even if you're enormous. Even if it takes you MONTHS to lose the weight! A year! I‘’1l love you always, Rone -- even if you GAIN weight after the baby. Verona makes no sign she’s hearing him.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (now quieter, as if he’s saying something really poignant now) Even if you gain so much weight I can’t find your vagina. She screams into the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (now whispering) Really. You can write that in stone, in your heart. I ... will -». love you ... even if... I can’t find your vagina.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona is listening to the baby’s heartbeat with a portab Doppler machine.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Her heart-rate is still pretty slow.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Like 115.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That’s normal enough, right?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s supposed to be between 120 and 160.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She's just mellow. Mellow’s good.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t want mellow now. I want lively now, mellow later.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I think it’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s because you don’t want to fight. We should fight more. Get her riled up.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Didn't we fight last night?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We discussed. We need to fight. You never raise your voice.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Fine. Okay... You did something wrong and I’m mad about it. Man, I am cross. Real mad.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. It has to be convincing.  62.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Should I swear?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. Just raise your voice.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (suddenly screaming) You cunt-sucker! Half the plane turns.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (in an urgent whisper) I didn’t mean now!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But the element of surprise is crucial! You’ve never heard me say cunt-sucker, have you? Verona has sunk so low in her seat that she’s talking int her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: See? I’ll get that heartrate up. I know what I’m doing. He pats her hand. She’s still recovering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive through a nice part of Hartford, and the begin of a tree-filled college campus.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: This is nice.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I haven’t seen Ellen in... I have no idea when I saw her last.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you thought to call her. Beat.  63.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Shit! My interview!

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How do you know? She opens his jacket. The itinerary is no longer stapled the lining of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
