dialogues.text: What did you do with it? Burt smiles. He’s got it figured out. He reaches down and takes off his shoe. He looks, but finds nothing inside. N the other shoe. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I wore the wrong shoes. They drive onto campus.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: So is Ellen a full professor, or an associate or...? And which side is she on -- she’s a first cousin?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Well, she’s not technically my cousin. Her mom was an old friend of my dad’s. I have no idea how. They started calling us cousins when we were kids. You met her at my brother's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She seemed really angry. She called the band racist.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She doesn’t think white people should play soul music. Verona scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Be nice.  64.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: They get out of their car and look around. Burt is trying call Ellen; he gets no answer.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You didn’t get the address?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She told me to call when I got to campus. The first person they see is a professor -- a woman of ab 38, with a baby in a stroller.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You wouldn’t happen to know where Ellen Forney-Fisher’s office is?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Ellen Forney-Fisher. (she says the name with a remarkable amount of distaste) Well I do know, as a matter of fact. She’s in Altgeld Hall. Room 340. In the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You think she’s there now? We’re early.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Well, if she’s not in her office, she’ll probably be around campus. She'll be the mom without the stroller. They thank the professor and head toward Altgeld.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're walking through the halls of the building, lookin for the room number.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She doesn’t have a stroller? I thought you said she got some big trust fund.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She did. Her mother married a Vanderbilt. Or a Carnegie. Which one did the pants? They arrive at the office. The door says LN HYLAND.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I thought her name was Ellen. What does L N stand for? It dawns on Verona that “Ellen” is spelled “LN.”

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She must have changed it. Don’t say anything about it. Please. He knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: LN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s open! They open the door upon a horrifying sight. There is a wo standing behind a desk. The woman has one baby in a sling and this baby is sucking on her left nipple. On the desk stands a four-year-old boy. He is sucking on her right nipple.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: (waving) Hello! The four-year-old peels his lips from the nipple and wave too.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR-YEAR-OLD
dialogues.text: Welcome! LN gestures them forward, in a “Come in! Come in!” sort o way. Burt and Verona are frozen. LN is about 37, blond, attractive, with luxurious curly hair. She’s wearing a wo poncho.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Come here, give me kisses! Verona and Burt proceed, their feet leaden. + eH  66. LN tucks her breasts back under her blouse and charges to Burt and Verona. The four-year-old wipes his mouth with t back of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: How are you two? Look at you! You're hardly showing! What a beauty you are, Verona. I thought something might have been wrong when you were so late.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. I blacked out.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: How inventive! You used to be so prompt, Burt. What are you doing to him, Verona? He was always on time... C’mon. (getting her bag and indicating the four-year- old) I have to get this one to crafting. The four-year-old puts on what seems to be a coat -- no, a cape, black and velvet -- and they all leave the office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're walking through the quad, on the way to their car

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. We tried to call you.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. I never answer the phone when I’m feeding. Not fair to the children. They walk past a protest -- dozens of students with signs (THE CIA TRAINED BIN LADEN) objecting to CIA recruiting o campus.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We got directions from a woman. She seemed to know you. She had a baby, very tall?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Oh god. Ruby Eng. She hates me. I breastfed her baby.  67.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: I was babysitting and the child was fussing -- he was starving, didn’t want the bottle. So I fed him. Took to me right away. I shouldn't have told her; she didn’t appreciate it. She has lactation problems. Now she won’t let me babysit, or get near her husband. How paranoid is that? So should we eat in? Out?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How about in? We’ve been traveling all day. Staying home would be so nice.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Okay... Let’s think of what I have at home...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Let us get the food! We have a car. We can go to the store and get whatever we need. It would be our pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Oh that’s great. Look at you, so helpful. I guess it’s in the blood. Verona has to take a second to figure out how many ways s was just insulted. They’re still walking through campus.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: I’m so glad you guys got pregnant so easily. To be honest, I had my doubts, given Verona’s tilted uterus. Oh, here I am. (indicating her car -- a Prius) I’1ll see you at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona is driving. Fuming.  68.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (furious) You told her I have a tilted uterus?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It might have been my mom. Is your tilted uterus a secret?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yeah my tilted uterus is a fucking secret! Something occurs to Burt.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh really, you fucking bitch? Your fucking uterus is a motherfucking secret? Well fuck you! Verona is shocked. Burt grabs the Doppler from the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is pushing the cart through the aisles.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Why don't we divide up? You get the wine and some beer and I'll get the pasta and vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don't want to get the wine. People give me bad looks when I buy wine.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You're being totally paranoid. Rone, you have to trust me on this. Nobody even notices you now that you're pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: That's supposed to make me feel better?  69. Verona goes to the wine section. She selects a few bottle red and white, and a six-pack of beer. As she makes her w back to Burt's cart, heads are turning, old women are whispering. A mother pushing her child in a cart hisses. She reunites with Burt near the checkout line.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We need a gift.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh god. Really?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We should. My parents will kill me if we don’t. (alighting on an idea) A stroller! They don’t have one! We'll be heroes. Look! He points out the window, across the parking lot, to a BA R US.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: If you check out, I’1l get the stroller. Burt is suddenly distracted. He’s spotted one of the chec out women, about 50, with large breasts.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (already making his way to the checkout) Good plan, good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona loading a stroller into the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is talking intensely with the large-breasted checkou woman. He’s got the checkout pen (the one on the spiral c and he’s taking notes on an empty paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So you're saying the trick is-- a * + FH FH HH FF

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You gotta stop breastfeeding at 6 months.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Interesting... There’s a loud buzzing or beeping sound from outside. Bur and the woman briefly look up but then resume their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And drink whole milk. And beer, lots of beer. Good for the mams.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (admiring her chest) They ARE good... The noise from outside continues. They again look up, try to find the source of all the racket.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And the thing about stretchmarks-- Wait. Is she with you? They both look up to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona leaning on the horn. It’s been her the whole time, watching Burt through the glass, furious. INT. LN’S HOUSE -- EVENING Burt and Verona ring the bell.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: One question about LN’s boobs and I throw you through that window. She's pointing to a second-story window.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That one, huh? Okay. Gotcha. LN opens the door, wearing a long flowing hippie robe-dre something like Joseph’s technicolor dreamcoat.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Namaste! * Burt and Verona = blank looks. *

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Come in! Come in! The spirit within * me salutes the spirit within you! * They step inside. We see that there's an elaborate cubby- like set-up of shoes and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind... Verona picks out a pair of black knitted slippers. Burt i left with one option: an elf-like pair, with pointed toes Welcome to greater Hartford! *

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Here, we brought you something. * Burt goes back to the porch to retrieve it. *

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: (to Verona) That is so sweet. Aren't you a dumpling? Burt presents the stroller, assembled, to LN. LN looks at like a rolling mound of pig shit is coming toward her.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Oh no... no, no. We don’t use those. No. Take it away.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: This is my house. Respect that, at LEAST! Take that thing away. Burt begins to roll the stroller into a side room. *

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: No! The porch. The door! Out! Burt opens the front door and wheels it out. *  72.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What the hell, LN?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Burt. I love my babies. Why would I push them away from me like that? (demonstrating with an aggressive move of pushing a stroller, as if off a cliff) No. We do continuum here. (in a hush, still traumatized) Yes. Continuum.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What is that -- continuum?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Continuum?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: (as if any mother-to-be should know) Continuum. LN and Verona stare each other down for a second.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Please, LN, you should just cut the shit and tell me. Burt raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (to Burt) Sorry. (faux-sweetly, to LN) I can’t wait to hear. Verona’s tone can’t keep LN from preaching the gospel.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: The Continuum movement recognizes that the world will give your baby plenty of alienation and despair in good time, so while we can we should hold them close.  73.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So you can’t push the kid ina stroller?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: No, no. Why do you think this country is so dysfunctional? Why we feel disconnected from our homes and loved ones?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Because of strollers?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: In this house we carry the children. We keep them attached. We don’t sever the biological ties at first opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What about sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are standing behind LN, who is showing th smallish, dimly lit, wood-paneled bedroom, dominated enti by a huge mattress. It’s almost twice the size of a king- bed.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: We have one bed. Sleep-time is their most fraught time, when they most need to know that their progenitors are near. Hi Roderick. It wasn’t clear at first, but RODERICK, LN’s partner, is laying on the bed. Roderick is tall, lanky, with longish dirty-blond hair and a broad open face. He turns over and greets them with a lazy wave. Both kids -- WOLF, 4, and NEPTUNE, 2 -- are laying with him, attached, in slings. T look barely able to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hi. I don’t think we’ve met. Burt tries to crawl over the bed on his knees, to shake Roderick’s hand. Roderick makes almost no effort.

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: Yes we have. Burning Man. 1997.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona looks at Burt, aghast. Burt quietly acknowledges t this is true. Burt and Verona take in the room. There are about two doz pictures of seahorses on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What about sex?

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You go out to the car or what?

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: No we don’t go out to the car. Are you planning to hide your lovemaking from your kids, Burt? Do you know what that does to a child, to have their parents’ expression of love kept a secret from them?

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: That’s why I have an Electra Complex.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Which one is that again?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: That’s when a woman wants to do her father. (to Roderick) Do you mean Oedipal Complex?

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: Don’t try to diagnose me, Verona.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (nodding toward the paintings) Why the seahorses, Rod? Roderick tries to answer, but emotion has overcome him.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: In the seahorse community, the males give birth. She gives Roderick a sympathetic look, as if to apologize  75.

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: The female inserts her ovipositor into the male’s brood pouch. That’s where she deposits her eggs.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: (with such tenderness) If I could, I would lay my eggs in your brood pouch.

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: (barely choking out the words ) I know you would. Burt and Verona are utterly stricken.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LN’S HOUSE -- EVENING -- DINNER TABLE At dinner, Verona, Burt, Roderick and LN are joined by LN son, WOLF, the four-year-old, wearing a sweater hand-made from hemp. NEPTUNE is on LN’s lap, playing with something LN’s neck -- it appears to be a vial of blood.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: It’s so good to have you two here.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (looking at the placemats, which look like abstract watercolors) These are very unusual.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Wolfie and Neptune helped make them. Didn't you, Wolfie? Wolf nods proudly.

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: So are you counting on this job interview tomorrow? At.. Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Providential. Not really. I already do fine. This would just be a better commission rate. +e HF FF *

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: It’s weird what you do, isn’t it, Burt? You sort of make money from people’s fears. The more the government and the media scares us, the more cash you haul in. Burt doesn’t take Roderick very seriously.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Nice to see you out of bed, Roderick.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR-YEAR-OLD
dialogues.text: Would you like a dolma?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FOUR-YEAR-OLD
dialogues.text: It’s an amuse-bouche.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FOUR-YEAR-OLD
dialogues.text: It means “pleasing to the mouth.” To whet your appetite.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay. Right. Thank you. He takes one.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Have you decided on a doula?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (holding up the appetizer Wolf gave him) I have one. Delicious.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: A doula, not a dolma.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We're not using a doula.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: A midwife?  77.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (finally catching on) Nope. No. Midwifes and doulas are for when the husband is clueless or doesn’t want to be involved. I am neither of those things. You know, I did successfully apply a tourniquet to a man and I've been doing some reading about the birth process...

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: The tourniquet? I was there. It was camp. We were twelve. Don’t you think Verona might need someone who understands the female experience?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We haven't decided yet exactly what we're doing--

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We don’t need some stranger in the delivery room who looks like Joan Baez.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Who what?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You know this is true. Every midwife I’ve seen -- they always look like Joan Baez. You know, with the short hair and the (demonstrating) pointy, lady sideburns.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) How’s Jim?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: My parents are fine, LN. They’re moving to Belgium.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Belgium? Whose idea was that? Sounds like Glenda’s.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What does that mean?  78.

dialogues.speaker: LN
dialogues.text: Uncle Jim was always more of a romantic. He wouldn’t have chosen Belgium. Don’t tell me they’re going to Antwerp.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Just stop. You’re way inappropriate about my dad. And don’t call him Uncle Jim. He’s not your uncle. Just ... gah.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Burt-—

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Dammit, LN, you've always done this. You and your mom always got too involved in my family. We really -- just don’t give us advice about the birth, okay?

dialogues.speaker: RODERICK
dialogues.text: Alice Walker says there’s nothing more important than how you enter this world, and I agree with her. My mom had a hospital birth -- the stirrups, the drugs, the machines. And she wonders why I can’t hold down a job, why I can’t walk into a dry cleaners without vomiting. It’s astonishing, her complicity in everything. And when I’m twelve she catches me with some peyote and I’m like, “What’d you expect? You started it with the epidural.”

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (putting his silverware down ) I’m going to ... put some quarters in the parking meter. Everyone knows there are no parking meters for miles, but one says a word. Burt walks out the front door. EXT. LN’S DRIVEWAY Verona has followed him outside. They’re standing in the gravel driveway.  They hug, 79.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about that. If I didn’t have to be almost related to her, I wouldn’t even bother.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I swear I didn’t tell her about your tilted uterus.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Thanks. and this leads to a small kiss, which leads to a passionate one, which leads to some groping. The action i getting heated.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We shouldn’t do this here.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Do you know what it does to a child to have their parents’ friends’ lovemaking kept a secret from them? What if I came and Wolfie didn’t get to witness it? I don’t want an Electra complex on my conscience. c'mon-- She takes off her shirt and pretends to walk back toward house.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Let’s go. He grabs her from behind and tries to lift her to wheel h around. He grunts involuntarily -- she’s heavier than he expected -- and never quite gets her off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are in the hotel room, both trying to capitalize on the sexual mood.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Okay, no more talking about LN.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: But she is nuts, right?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She’s an awful person. An unholy union of intentions and pretensions. Burt is lying in the bed and Verona is putting on a nightgown, something distinctly unflattering. We see Burt examining the nightgown, forming a thought.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey Verona... Verona immediately can sense that an unsolicited remark a her appearance is coming.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. Burt. C’mon, don’t blow it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I just want to tell you one little thing.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Burt, I’m helping you out here. (kneeling on the bed, crawling toward him) Just stop talking. I don’t want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You don’t know what I’m going to say.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I do.  81. Verona goes into the bathroom and closes the door. Burt g up and stands on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Verona. Listen. No response.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Verona. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Please. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I was just going to say that I don’t think you look good in that. She screams a frustrated scream and walks out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona is sitting in the lobby, on the couch, in her nightgown. She’s watching TV with the HOTEL MANAGER, Indi and in his 60s. Burt takes a second to process the scene, then awkwardly sits between Verona and her new friend.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m such a jerk. Verona says nothing. There are tears of frustration in he eyes. She gets up and walks toward the elevator. Burt follows.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Man am I stupid. Nothing from Verona.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I am the worst. I know it. Verona seems to be softening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in and Burt embraces Verona from behind, his ha around her waist. Verona relents, resting her hands on hi

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What can I do? Say it. Anything. Verona smiles, thinking of something.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You want me to come on your tits? Now she bawls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt’s interview is over. He and Verona have gathered at cafe. Verona is at the counter, alone.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Can I get a small latte?

dialogues.speaker: BARRISTA
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Am I sure about what?

dialogues.speaker: BARRISTA
dialogues.text: It has caffeine.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: That's the point. The barrista points to Verona’s stomach. Now Verona gets

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Just give me the latte, Doctor. And a muffin. She gets her drink and muffin and finds Burt and sits dow He has his laptop open.  83.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh god. The myth that people are nicer to pregnant women... White men cut me in every line because I'm slower -- they think I’m weak. And every woman thinks the baby’s theirs, that I’ve asked them to judge me. The only people who know how to treat me are black men. At that moment, a black man in the cafe, maybe on the effeminate side, notices her.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: The goddess is alive!

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (to Burt) See? (stirring her coffee) How was the interview?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It was so weird. He kept saying things about how I didn’t look like my picture, how he expected someone else... He was confused. It was awkward.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Huh. (something dawns on her) Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Your website.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What about it?  84. She grabs Burt’s laptop and types in a url. Up pops Burt’ website, which features information about insurance futur and Burt's business philosophy, and, over the name BURT FARLANDER, a picture of a handsome, silver-haired 58-year man, in a perfect suit, sitting on the corner of a desk.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That was your idea.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I thought it fit the voice. Sorry. They sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: How long till the flight leaves?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Six hours. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: LN signed us up for a birth class.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Of course she did.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We haven’t been to one. We have nothing else to do. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Could be funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We join Burt and Verona as they’re leaving for a mid-clas break. They file out of the room with all of the other couples. Trailing behind is CONNIE, the woman running the class. She looks exactly like -- or is actually played by Joan Baez.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Ten minutes and come back. The hard part is over.  85.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (whispering to Burt) I'm actually surprised. This class has been almost completely normal.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She’s not all bad. Verona goes to the bathroom. Burt is at the vending machi when he’s approached by a man of about 35, bearded, athle - he looks like a 70s-era football player.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: You gonna watch?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Burt has his hand inside the machine, trying to retrieve Twizzlers.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Which side of the curtain you gonna be on?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: In the delivery room? I’1l be right there. I’m gonna watch every minute.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Don’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m gonna do it.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Don't do it, man. Those movies we watched (indicating the classroom)... They don’t show anything.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You've been through this?

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah. My first wife. Listen. How big a man are you? (indicating Burt’s pants) Let's assume you’re average. He takes Burt’s Twizzlers and peels one strand of licoric off the bunch.  86.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Now, for years now, your Twizzler has had a nice, warm, compact docking bay waiting for it, right? Burt tries to straighten the Twizzler, which has drooped.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Now you’re sitting in the delivery room, thinking “miracle of life,” “spectacle of birth,” right? But here’s your Twizzler. And here’s the size of a baby. Once that humanoid comes out of your wife, are you ever gonna be able to see your wife’s -- excuse me -- tootie the same way again? No sir. That space is no longer yours. It’s like they built a superhighway in your childhood bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: A what? Where?

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: My first wife did 1000 Kegels a day and I swear she had the loosest slot outside of Reno. I shit you not -- I could stick a baby right back in there with the hole she had. Wouldn’t need a lubricant. Ask me how much sex we had after that.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: None. Now ask me why we got divorced.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Ask me why my son is living in Mexico City with a semi- professional soccer player they call The Bandito.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Stay behind the curtain, my man. Don’t be a hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are five or six other couples there, fairly nondescript; if anything, they’re a bit on the artsy side They're gathered in a semi-circle.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay gang. Now, finally: If there’s one thing I want you to take away from this, it’s that the placenta... Here she removes the towel that has been covering a jar. Inside the jar is what appears to be some kind of long- pickled sea squid.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (in an urgent whisper) Oh Jesus. No. The squid is purple, red, and tentacled. Burt’s jaw drops open. He loves it.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: .-.-is not your enemy.... She lifts the jar and begins walking it around the room.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh lord god.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s not some disgusting thing to be thrown away at first opportunity. As you may know, in some cultures...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: That’s always bad, when they say “in some cultures...” Burt is still enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: «+. the placenta is buried in the backyard after a birth. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONNIE (cont'd) In others, it’s cooked and eaten by the family.... Burt is still wide-eyed, while Verona looks pale, and is listing heavily, as if seasick.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I want to introduce another option, one that I’ve had the pleasure of seeing work very well with many couples at this facility. Are there any artists here? All but two of the attendees raise their hands. Everyone’ artist. Burt raises his, too. The one actual artist in th room, Verona, has her arms folded.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: So you know the pleasures of working with archival-quality watercolor paper. Now imagine the power of a relief print of your placenta, if applied to high- density archival watercolor paper. She holds up a sample. Oohs and ahhs ensue. There is gene agreement among the attendees that this is a superb idea.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Why do those look familiar...?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh no. It dawns on Burt and Verona that this is what LN’s placem were -- laminated placenta prints.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Now you’re probably wondering, “How big should the paper be? And how Many good transfers can you get before the placenta becomes too dry?”.. Verona sighs loudly, leans her head on Burt’s shoulder, a closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're packing to leave for the airport. Burt finds something in his suitcase -- the video camera.  89.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Damn. We’ve totally forgotten to be documenting.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You’re not serious.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Rone, you want no record of this whole miraculous transformation?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I want no cheap ugly grainy video record of this miraculous transformation. Burt’s already got the camera out and is hooking it into tripod.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Let’s go. Get naked. And get up against the window there, with the light. It’1l look cool. Verona not-so-reluctantly complies. Soon she’s undressed standing near the window, with a soft light falling on he curves.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That’s nice. Nice. Now stand on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Please? You want it to look artistic, don’t you? Stand on the chair. Like this. (indicating one leg up, like a flamingo) Soon she’s in the desired position, and Burt gets the vid camera ready.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So glad I brought the tripod. It’s gonna be good... Okay, ready?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Ready. Burt turns the camera on. His eyes go wide.  90.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What? Through the viewfinder, we see that there’s a tape alread the camera. The frame shows a very un-pregnant Verona, na standing in much the same position as she is at the momen The contrast is interesting: in the video, the color is l and cheap. Just beyond, in the hotel room, Verona is illuminated softly, and looks ethereal.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What is it? Burt is watching, eyes popping.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You didn’t bring the tape.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (in quiet awe) It’s in the camera. Verona comes down off the chair and around to Burt. Toget they slowly sit down on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh god. I haven’t seen this since we made it. Burt and Verona sit attentively on the edge of the bed. T tape begins. It’s a homemade sex video. The camera has be left on a bookshelf by their bed, and has captured Burt a Verona engaging in a relatively standard sex session. We watch Verona and Burt as they watch the tape, and the that comes over their faces is one of utter melancholy. T miss those days. A song begins as Verona and Burt both begin to get teary. That song is “The Way We Were.” We watch them watch themselves humping, and the lyrics begin. Memories Like the pages of my mind Misty watercolor memories Of the way we were...  gl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Way We Were” continues, wall-to-wall. Verona is sitting on the plane, alone, peaceful. The seat next to her -- Burt’s -- is unoccupied. Suddenly he appears behind her. Screaming. Though we can’ hear him, it’s clear he’s cursing loudly. Verona’s eyes o Everyone on the plane turns, aghast. “The Way We Were” continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona and Burt are outside a beautiful walk-up in a clea and charming neighborhood of the city.**

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We went to the same college as these guys. We graduated the same year. How can they be so grown up while we're...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Immature? Stunted? Confused? American? They ring the doorbell. The chime is a novelty -- the sou of a mild electric shock, and someone reacting to it:

dialogues.speaker: DOORBELL
dialogues.text: Zzzzt. Ahhh! Burt plays with the doorbell for a minute -- Zzzzt! Aaaaa Zzzzzzt! Aaaaaah! A 5-year-old Chinese girl answers the d

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Hi. Are your parents home?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: They're in their room.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey Abigail. Abby. Remember me? She shakes her head. Burt is mildly hurt.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Should we come in?  92.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Abby leads them into the house and into the TV room, wher four kids are splayed out all over a system of couches. T kids are JAMES, 16 and white; on his lap is STUART, a 6-y old South African boy. Nearby is KATYA, 10, an adoptee fr Kazakhstan wearing a huge rainbow afro wig. Together they all watching The Sound of Music.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It’s almost over. Verona and Burt are encouraged to sit and watch. The movie is at the point where the Von Trapp children perform their “So long, farewell,” song. Just after the s - and before any Nazis appear, the movie abruptly ends, a the credits roll. The lights come on and the kids begin t sit and stand up.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Wait. What--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shh. TOM GARNETT, the father of the children, appears. He’s ab 37, handsome, unaffected, dressed to go clubbing. He walk through the room, touching all of the children’s heads in very comfortable and very affectionate way. He’s a big- hearted, magnanimous guy. Each of the kids loves the attention -- their bond with him is undeniable -- though Stuart, who thinks he’s a dinosaur, tries to bite Tom’s h Tom now motions Burt out of the room. Verona follows and three of them huddle in the kitchen. Tom gives hugs to bo Burt and Verona.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Great to see you guys! (to Verona) You look amazing, Verona. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So, uh... Burt gestures back to the TV room.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We sorta edited it.  93.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You cut out the Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. We kinda figured, What’s the point, you know?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: They haven’t caught on?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Not yet. Not even the oldest. Or maybe he has, but he plays along. You won’t tell them about the Nazis?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (genuinely relieved) Thanks man. I appreciate that. There are always people who want the kids to know everything right away -- sex! war! genocide! But we think the longer we can keep them from knowing about the Nazis, the better. They heard something about Pol Pot a few months ago and I was doing spin control for a week. Hey Munch! MUNCH, Tom’s wife, walks down the stairs and greets every Munch is casual, confident, with a huge and convincing sm She's also preppy, almost conservative-seeming at first glance. They all go back into the family room.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Kids, this is Verona and Burt. Your mom and I went to college with them. Munch is staring at Verona, with sudden tears in her eyes Abby, the 5-year-old, pulls up a kids’ chair so she can s at Verona’s stomach; Munch keeps a strange distance. Meanwhile, Stuart, the 6-year-old, takes Burt’s hand and leads him to a corner of the couch. He positions Burt to as if he’s lounging on the couch, about to take a nap. St then climbs onto the arm of the couch.  94. Burt sits on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Lie there.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay. Stuart arranges Burt so he’s on the couch, resting agains one end, as if taking a nap.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: Close your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay. Burt closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Gah! Stuart has jumped from the arm of the couch, onto Burt’s stomach, feet first.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to Munch and Tom) What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: That’s Garfield. You’re John. The cartoon. You’re napping, he leaps on you. This is the game.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Do it again. Burt complies. Again Stuart jumps on him, which hurts lik mother. This continues as someone is tapping Verona on th shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (seeing over Verona’s shoulder) You have a visitor. Someone important. Verona turns around. There is a tall person, very small- faced, wearing a raincoat. It’s Abby, sitting on the shoulders of her sister Katya.  95.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (in very serious, KGB voice) Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I have a question for you.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Do you know the way to San Jose?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Okay you guys. We have to go now. Your mom and dad are going to tear up the town. James’1ll watch you. Burt is still on the couch, getting assaulted by Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (with eyes closed) How many times does John get woken up by Garfield? Blank stares all around. It could take a while.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Close your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We'll get the car and meet you out front. James, we'll be back late. Lock up and give Katya her medicine. And you have my cell.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I do. Have fun. Burt slips away from Stuart and meets Tom near the hall - they're putting on their coats.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Who’s that? The tall one... You would have been about 18...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: James? He’s not mine. He’s a kid who lives down the street. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOM (cont'd) He worked on our crew over the summer, good with wood, drywall, and ... (as if it just occurred to him) I guess he lives with us now. His dad’s a meth addict. His mom’s a bassist. Good kid. Wants to be an architect. EXT. GARRETT’S HOUSE Verona and Burt are walking down the steps, on the way to street. Verona clutches Burt’s sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (rapturously) This is the family I want. Every part of it. The kids from all over the world--

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: So you want to adopt?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (pointing to her stomach) What about this one? Should we trade her in? I bet we could get two Chinese girls, or three Russians--

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. I want her, and them, too. I want to live in a big house like this, with all the kids, and the couches, and carpets, and have everyone laying all over each other like that. This is a family.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah. It works. It’s real.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We should move here. Montreal. These guys’ll be our best friends and our daughter will be friends with all these kids. And she won’t have any of the American baggage! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERONA (cont'd) She won’t have to pretend to be Canadian when she backpacks through Europe... Think of that. Tom and Munch screech to a halt beside them, driving a sm older sports car. Munch is already drinking from a flask. is at the wheel and is wearing driving gloves.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Let’s do this. INT. TOM’S CAR Tom is driving very fast. Verona and Burt are in the back seat. They’re passing the flask around. Music blares. The gone into high party mode with incredible speed.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: So you still find time to go out?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We’re out a lot, I guess. Depends on when. You have to find that balance. I mean, the kids want you there, but not all the time. They need air as much as you do.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I think we’re moving here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: To Montreal? We already won the competition? Over Hartford? Over Phoenix? Hell yeah!

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Let’s toast. Does anyone know a toast? No one knows a toast.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: Okay. So... Yay for Burt and Verona moving here. Probably if they’re not stupid. They all cheer.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're at a casual bar, eating dinner while a jazz combo plays in the background. Tom and Burt are turned toward t band. Munch and Verona are having a private talk.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: So did it take you guys a long time to get pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I think it was the first shot. Beginner's luck.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s wonderful. It’s clear that Munch doesn’t really find that news so wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: Any problems so far?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Not so far. (now sensing that she shouldn’t be smug about this) I've been crying a little more than usual.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: You're not pregnant, are you? You look--

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: No, no. No. A couple walks by and sees Munch’s drink on the table. Th assume Verona is drinking while pregnant, and give her a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I can’t stand it. Tom leans in.  99.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We need to eat real food. I need bacon.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: (to Verona) He needs bacon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them are in a booth. Tom is feasting on a lar stack of pancakes, with an enormous side of bacon. The ot three are drinking tea. Burt has a piece of apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (his face full of pig fat) Wait. So you're still not married? Burt, when are you going to propose?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Propose? All I do is propose. (to Verona) Verona, will you marry me? Verona does a quick shake of her head, as if she’s saying to fresh pepper on her salad.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: (to Verona) Is this true? It’s you who’s behind this?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I can’t see the point.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: There isn’t any, really. Not unless you have parents who care one way or the other, which you don’t. Maybe there isn’t really a point. Is there a point, Tom? Tom shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: It’s a nice tradition, though.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Your wedding was nice.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: It was, wasn’t it? Now Tom has finished his bacon and is ready to expound.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know what you need to be happy? Munch rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You need this. Tom is holding up the maple syrup.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Here’s you two guys. He takes two sugar cubes from the bowl on the table.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Or wait. He replaces one of the sugars with a brown one.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Okay. So you have you two. And let’s say here’s the baby. He takes a smaller brown cube and adds it to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And here’s your house. He uses toothpicks to enclose the three of them in a very crude house, with a coaster for a roof.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But what is this? Is that home, is that a family? No, no. Course not. That's just the raw material -- the people, the walls, the furniture, your jobs, maybe a nanny or grandmother. The basics. That’s not a family, that’s not a home. The thing that binds it all together is this. Now he holds up the maple syrup.  101.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Awesome. He begins to pour it all over the sugar and toothpicks.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This is love.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This is your love, guys, your patience, your consideration, your better selves. Man, you just have no idea how good you can be! But you have to use all of it. (the syrup is everywhere now, inches of it) It’s not like simple brick and mortar, where you use a little layer of mortar between the bricks. With this, you have to use TONS of it. For every brick, there’s a half- ton of mortar.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I thought we were doing syrup.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Mortar, syrup, whatever. It’s the same. It’s the glue. It’s all those good things you have in you -- the love, the wisdom, the generosity, the selflessness, the patience. Patience at 3am, patience after work, patience when you feel like your life is passing you by and you're waiting for your baby to burp -- you have to amp that patience aspect so much it’1l make you sick. Reaction shot from Burt, who is staring at the mess of sy and sugar and coasters.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And you have to be willing to make the family out of whatever you have. We’ve got a Chinese girl, a South African AIDS baby, a Russian orphan. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOM (cont'd) We've got a teenager from down the street who wanted some stability -- he likes to eat dinner at 7 every night. So he cooks for us sometimes -- anything to know that at 7, he'll be at a table, with six other faces, a plate of hot food in front of him. But the point is largesse, is breaking the piggy bank of your own love. Man, you have to be so much better than you ever thought!

dialogues.speaker: MUNCH
dialogues.text: And once a week Tom and I go out and at least one of us comes home wasted... And it works, I think.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: And the kids never know.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Once in a while Munch gives me a hickey and I wear a turtleneck the next day. The kids are none the wiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Tom are at a table near the stage, both of them drunk. There is a sign near the bar that reads AMATEUR NI

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: There are a lot of couples here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s Montreal. World capital of this kind of shit. Where’s Verona?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Bathroom. Where’s Munch? Tom points to the stage, onto which Munch is crawling. Cy Lauper’s “Girls Just Want to Have Fun” kicks in and Munch begins dancing. Burt watches, aghast and fascinated. Munch is at first awkward, beginning a routine, but then grows more comfortable. She knows what she’s doing, and has done it before. She takes off her blouse, revealing a slinky tank top.  103.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Uh oh. She’s using the pole now. Don’t you want to say something?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nah. Let her go. Munch continues to dance -- a desperate sort of dance, a dance of loss and defiance. The song, when you really lis to it, is a sad one, too. Someone takes a beautiful girl And hides her away From the rest of the world... Verona walks into the room at that moment. She sees Munch the stage and freezes. After a moment, her eyes and Munch meet; volumes pass between them.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Burt) She had another miscarriage.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No. Just this Thursday-- ?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hell, Burt. We’ve had too many miscarriages. They take so much out of you. This is her fifth. I know she loves all those kids like they were her own blood, but... They watch Munch. Verona hasn’t moved -- she’s still standing, frozen. The song is, in this context, powerful, searing, and Munch’s dance is one of great melancholy and power. At this point, Verona turns to Burt, and they lock eyes. Tom continues talking to Burt, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I wonder if we’ve been selfish, people like us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOM (cont'd) We wait until we’re thirty-five and then we’re surprised that the babies aren’t so easy to make anymore... All the while, Burt and Verona are staring at each other. They know how lucky they are.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: ..-And every day another million fourteen-year-olds get pregnant without trying... I just wish I could make it work for her. If I could fix it all and just grow a baby for her. It’s terrible feeling this helpless, man. You just watch these babies grow and then fade and you don’t know if you’re supposed to name them or bury them or... I’m sorry. The song is ending and Munch is stepping down from the st to many cheers. Tom helps Munch off the steps and she sits on his lap, holding him fiercely. From either side of the couple, Verona and Burt stare at other intensely, feeling very lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona wakes up, hearing what seems to be a muffled conversation. She looks over and sees that Burt’s not the She looks around; the voice she hears is close, and is Burt’s, but he’s not visible. She looks in the bathroom: Burt. She opens the door to the bedroom: no Burt in the hallway. In fact, whenever she ventures from the bed, the voice grows fainter. Eventually she squats down, realizing that Burt is -- cou he really be? -- under the bed. She finds him there. He’s the phone. Finally he sees her.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (to the phone) Hold on a sec. Rone’s up. (to Verona) It’s Courtney. (back into the phone) No. I’m telling her now. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURT (cont'd) (back to Verona) We're going to Miami.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Verona and Burt are getting dressed in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t he tell you sooner?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: He’s embarrassed. He’s my brother.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. Grace would have told me right away.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: This is different. It’s embarrassing if your wife leaves you. She just left, Verona. They never fought, nothing. That’s a sign that there’s some other guy, or she was just bored or whatever. It’s hard enough that he’s a dentist. He’s already sensitive about that kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: About being left.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: About being boring. Helena was-- It’s not fair to say now, but she was always a reach for him. She was- - he knew I wasn’t that crazy about her. I felt like she always had one eye open for something better.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Poor Courtney. How old is Annabelle?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Eight.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I know, I know. They walk downstairs. The entire family is eating waffles Tom and Munch are wearing turtlenecks.  106.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You guys want blueberry or chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, the plane ride is more melancholy. They have a on their minds. Verona sleeps across Burt’s lap. All arou them are soldiers -- National Guard of all ages -- on the way to or from Iraq or elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona ride, still preoccupied by the news of Courtney's wife’s departure. The stunning scenery has no effect on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at Burt’s brother’s office. It’s in a small h just outside of Miami’s downtown. The skyline is visible the background. It’s a cozy dentist’s office with signs o front that welcome kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s cozy inside too, though the waiting room is decorate with posters and memorabilia celebrating the supremacy of 70s art-rock band YES. Sitting at the appointment window is not an adult secreta but a girl of eight. She has a pencil behind her ear. Thi ANNABELLE. She hears the bells when the door opens, but doesn’t look

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Are you Mrs. Alvarez?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: No. Are you ... eight? Annabelle looks up and brightens when she sees Verona. Bu emerges from behind Verona and Annabelle’s face explodes a phosphorescent smile.  107.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Burp!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey Bellbottom! Come here. Burt’s niece is cute in an awkward sort of way, with dark rings around her eyes. Seeing Burt has her face contorted into a wild sort of grin. She can’t wait -- she crawls through the window and jumps the edge and into Burt’s arms. Burt lifts her over his he and then hugs her for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (whispering into her hair) Hi sweetie-pie poop-a-loop. I missed you so much. Annabelle is too deep in a bliss-high to speak. She rests chin on Burt’s neck and chews her gum silently, her tiny finger playing in Burt’s hair. The moment is broken by a loud yelp from inside.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: Holy mother of god! In a few seconds, COURTNEY, about 37, with shaggy hair an glasses, emerges. There’s blood on his uniform.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: (wiping his hands) Hey! I thought you weren’t coming till tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: We got an early flight.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Verona! You look fantastic. He gives her a warm hug. While they embrace, he sees Burt almost instantly tears up.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Hey brother.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey brother.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Can you leave now?  108.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maria? Maria, a young dental assistant, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Can you finish Mr. Hyland?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t--

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Do your best.

dialogues.speaker: EXT--MIAMI STREET--DAY
dialogues.text: They leave the office and walk out to the street. Courtne looks up at the sun as if he hasn’t seen it in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I'll drive. You hungry? I’m here. They arrive at his car. It’s a new Volvo.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Nice. Courtney can’t find his keys.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I had em here. He looks in his backpack. No luck. He checks and rechecks pockets.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Belle, did I give em to you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: No. Now he’s looking under the car.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You think they’re under the car?

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Shush! I have a spare down here. (fumbling) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COURTNEY (cont'd) (from under the car) GODDAMMIT. He gets up, and slowly composes himself.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: (adopting a tone somewhere between saccharine and about-to-explode) Bella, are you sure I didn’t give them to you? Remember that sometimes you’re wrong. You were wrong yesterday when I asked if you had already brought in the mail and then we didn’t see that check that Dad needed. Remember that? Annabelle nods.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: So do you have them?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: I'll go inside. Courtney is vibrating. His frustration is far out of proportion to the problem at hand.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: C’mere, big brother. Burt takes him aside and they huddle.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey. This isn’t you. I can’t let you snap at Bella that way.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I don’t blame you, Cort. I mean, this whole thing... Burt sees Annabelle as she emerges from the office withou the keys. Seeing all four of them standing by the corner, cab slows, and Burt hails it.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Get in. Courtney complies and they all pile in.  110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the restaurant and walk along the South Beach promenade. Verona and Annabelle walk ahead, inexplicably giving military salutes to everyone they pass. They pass parent with a five-year-old boy on a leash. Annabelle and Verona exchange looks. Burt and Courtney walk some distance behind.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Have you heard from her?

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Not a word. They walk a few steps.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Isn’t that strange? She was never like that, really. She was kind of normal, right?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: She was pretty normal.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: You know how many times I’ve checked our messages? I check them ten times an hour. I got all the lines to bounce to my cellphone. Maybe she was kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But you said she left a note.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. But it might have been coerced.... Beat. Courtney comes to his senses.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I guess not. It’s so weird. I've never felt so emasculated. I feel like such a chump. And the rage!

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (remembering the car-key episode) Yeah.  111.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I have to invent new ways of dealing with it every night. I destroyed all the lawn furniture.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What’d you use?

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Nine iron.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (interested) Not a wedge...

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I’m so confused, though. Part of me is so angry I don’t want to ever see her again. I mean, I have all these daydreams of her in prison, and getting painful tattoos all over her body. And on the other hand I just want her back and things to be the same.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Belle seems okay.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s even weirder.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What’d you tell her?

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: At first I said it was a business trip. I made the mistake of telling her it'd be five days. I actually thought that was a conservative estimate. I thought I’d have figured it out by then. Then five days went by and Belle wanted to know where she was. So I said her grandpa died. Burt looks mildly shocked.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: It took her mind off of her mom for a while. They walk.  112.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: I really need help. With what to do next. Sorry I called. I just... If she’s really gone for good, I need to know what to say. It’s wrong to say Helena was murdered, right?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: That might be traumatic.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there’s finality there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courtney, Burt and Verona are all sitting on Annabelle’s acting out a story together.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: And then the bullfrog said... Silence. All eyes are on Verona.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Wait, was that me? I’m the bullfrog, too? The answer is yes. Verona looks at the page.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (adopting the voice of a bullfrog) Where is my crown? I need my crown!

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: And to that the wolverine said:

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (in a German accent) “You vill nevah have your crown, stinky bullfrog! I have buried it under zah giant acacia tree! Ha ha ha ha ha!” Burt’s wolverine voice and maniacal laugh are a bit over top.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: And so the story ends. At least tonight it does. Say goodnight to Uncle Burp and Verona.  113. Burt and Verona each lean down and give hugs to Annabelle who seems desperately happy that they’re there. Annabelle settles into bed and then looks at Verona.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Your boobs are soft.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: My mom’s are harder.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Okay. EXT. COURTNEY’S PORCH -- LATER THAT NIGHT Burt and Courtney and Verona are on the porch. Verona is asleep on an Adirondack chair. Courtney pulls something from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: You see this? It’s Annabelle’s new school picture.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (examining it) That’s cute. What’s on her upper lip?

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Carrot juice.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: She just took this on Monday. Remember when we had to wait weeks for the school pictures? Anyway... So this is the picture. I don’t see the carrot juice on her mouth when she leaves the house. I’m never going to see these things. Moms see the carrot juice on their daughters’ mouths. Moms know when their daughters aren’t dressed right. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COURTNEY (cont'd) Moms go shopping with them, and make sure their hair doesn’t look spazzy. In one fell swoop Helena has changed this girl’s life from a normal one, where she can be popular and all that, to the distinct likelihood that she’s going to be introverted, a poor dresser -- one of those girls who looks longingly at the girls who have new shoes and the right backpack...

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (suddenly awake) At least it was carrot juice. Not whisky.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: It’s just the beginning, though. Things devolve from here. I’1l be spending every waking moment trying to reconstruct a normal life, but everyone around will have more tools, more money, more ability to form a regular family. And Annabelle will always be the girl without a mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona wakes up, notices Burt’s not there. She hears his muffled voice, looks out the window and sees him on the b patio, with a phonebook open, pacing while talking on his cellphone. She comes downstairs and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m looking for her. I’m calling anyone she knew. Her old company, her friends --

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: At 2 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Right. Element of surprise.  115. Verona notices the broken patio furniture -- victims of Courtney's frustration.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Stop, please. Burt sits down. Then stands up. He’s so agitated he can’t stay still. Finally he gets onto Annabelle’s trampoline - big rectangular one, 3 feet off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (now jumping) What kind of goddamned person would leave her daughter?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (watching him go up and down ) I don’t know. Maybe not such a strong person. Please stop.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (not stopping) And there’s nothing we can do. She's gone. This family can’t be fixed. That’s it. What if one of us freaks out like that?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We won't. And it can be fixed and you know it. And if you don’t stop jumping I will find a way to hurt you with that shovel. She points to a large iron shovel. Burt stops jumping.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: C'mere. Sit down. He pulls her onto the trampoline. Soon they’re both on th knees, facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: But really -- what if something happens to one of us and makes us crazy? Like what if I walk by a construction site and something falls and my frontal lobe gets chopped off and my personality is altered and then I’m not a good dad. What if that happens? Verona doesn’t know how much she should humor him.  116.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: We'll be careful walking near construction sites.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: And what about Munch?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: She'll be careful near construction sites, too.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: No really. Don’t you just look at her and want to give her everything she wants? It’s insanely unfair that she can’t--

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Of course it’s unfair. She can’t conceive, and bad parents still get to be parents, and good parents die when their daughters are in high school. So what.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Rone.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: All we can do is be good for this one baby. We don’t have control over much else.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Let’s get married at least.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Never. Burt's visibly disappointed. He really thought she’d say this time.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: But I’1l never leave you.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (dejected) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I promise.  117.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Okay. (pause) You promise to never marry me because you don’t want to marry me without your parents there -- and I get that -- and you promise to never leave me. But do you promise to never leave this baby we're having? Unless maybe part of your brain gets knocked off by an I- beam?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I do. And do you promise to stop talking about your ability to find or not find my vagina after I give birth?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I do. And do you promise to let me cobble--

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Carve.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: To carve in my spare time and teach our daughter the lure of the great Mississippi?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I do. And do you promise to never try to make art out of my placenta or any other bodily discharge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're lying down now, face to face. Burt has found a tarpaulin and pulled it over themselves.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I do. And do you promise to let our daughter be fat or skinny or any weight at all because we want her to be happy no matter what and eating disorders are too stupid and cliche for our daughter?  118.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I do. And do you promise to raise this kid without fear -- without child-leashes and fences and without buying into the insane and almost totally unfounded child- abduction paranoia crippling our nation?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I do. And do you promise, if I get one of those parasites that creeps up your nose after you go swimming in certain shallow lakes and then slowly eats your brain and you die within a week, that you’ll lie and tell our daughter that her father was killed by Russian soldiers in intense hand-to-hand combat so he could save 850 Chechnyan orphans? They're both fading now. Verona’s eyes are closed.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Yes, Chechnyan orphans... I do... And do you promise that sometime tonight we'll figure out where the hell we’re going to live with this baby, coming very soon into this world?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Verona are entwined on the trampoline. They’ve fallen asleep there, after talking half the night. Annabelle comes outside, crawls onto the trampoline and kneels next to them. She pokes Verona’s breast.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: They really are softer. Burt and Verona wake up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: You're supposed to come inside like normal people and eat food that normal people eat, inside like normal people.  119. She goes inside. Burt and Verona follow slowly. They catc themselves, remembering what they decided the night befor

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I had a dream we made a really strange decision.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I think it’s the right one, though. Don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I honestly have no idea. All I know is that I can barely breathe just thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: (at the door, waiting) Are you normal people or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all eating breakfast. We catch them mid-conversat Burt and Verona have figured out where they’re going next where they’re probably going to live -- and have just tol Courtney.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You're welcome to come. There’s room.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: It sounds good. I think it’s the right thing for you guys. But no, I better stay here for now. Annabelle’s in the school play. She’s the lead.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (to Annabelle) Really? What’s the play?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: (with a mouth full of oatmeal, using her spoon to make a stabbing motion) Medea.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: But maybe someday. I don’t know. Is Grace coming?  120.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Ew. You can’t go after Grace now. I know you always lusted after her but that would be too weird.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: Hey -- I was just asking. Idle curiosity. Burt winks at him; they share a lascivious sort of look, thinking of Grace. INT. BURT AND VERONA’S CAR -- DAYTIME -- ROLLING HILLS It’s late Spring. Verona is a month or so more pregnant. and Verona are driving through an unfamiliar landscape. Hilly, semi-rural, beautiful, maybe a bit run-down.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Is it starting to look familiar?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (uncertain) I think so... I want it to... But I also want it to be new, you know? New for us? New enough to feel like we found it? Does that make sense?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (seeing something) Oh god, I remember that! They both look at a tree in front of someone’s yard, decorated with a dozen kinds of fruit -- apples, oranges, bananas, pineapples. The owner has strung fake fruit from branches.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I have to call Grace. (she dials) Yup, we’‘re almost there. (pause) No, I’m fine. (pause) It is! That’s why I called. We just passed it. Pineapples! Yes. No, I didn’t see the cantaloupe... (to Burt) Wait, that was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've just missed a turn.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: (to Grace) I’1ll call you after we get there. Love you. She hangs up. Sighs. Burt backs up.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I am. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I am. They head down a narrow winding road canopied by wisteria kudzu. Burt is clearly in heaven; it’s the landscape of h dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull up to a Victorian house, three-storied and gran though in disrepair.

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Oh! I forgot how beautiful it is. We realize this is Verona’s childhood home, the same hous saw in the photo in Grace and Verona’s offices. It’s dilapidated but full of character and potential. They park and get out of the car. There’s a creek running through the property; a bridge ov it connects the driveway to the front door. Burt is astounded, taking it all in.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I love your parents so much right now. They were geniuses. This is what I want for our baby. Tears burst from Verona. As they walk toward the front door, Verona leans on Burt strength. She hasn’t been back home in 10 years. +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the doorway, Burt opens it and Verona has to steady herself on the frame. She slowly slides down until she’s sitting, overwhelmed. Burt sits with Verona, looking around the house, inside a out.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: This is really us, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: I think it is. I fucking hope so. We pull back until we’re outside the door. The door close THE END.
